There machines this country than before.
There automobiles and telephones in the nation
and the numbers rplanes Is increasing steadily in the private
market,


Too often young boys and girls elementary school and
high school will they plan be DOCTORS lawyers teachers
They realize that become lawyer doctor
other professional worker.


The fields in automove and electrical engineering
Daily plants send in the continental United States and
abroad search for skilled technicians.


Many young who unable find jobs might have been
led northumberland before they quit school,


No longer should diploma bear stigma
We should think that Of low mentality failing school
grades the only who be utilized In vocational
technical Too often the States the programs
suffered because have unable
boy girl these types Of programs before they reach their junior

Mo REVIEWS


Edward Banks

The division of political life in these
United States is divided between two
major parties, the Republican and the
Democratic. WSthin books sVyitten on
politics, politicians and political times,
attempts haze been MADE to show the dis
tinctions and differences or the sinilaTs-
ties and HkeneSSeS Of the t1VO major
parties.


In the past years, PARTY leaders OF both
the Democrats and Republicans haze taken
credit for many things in our nations
history from ending MARS to promoting
the FLOW of Wutey IN dams. However,
there are men and women 10llo make UP
the party structures in all block, pre-
ciucts, wards and counties throughout the
aosO fifty states, uVho neUeY get credit.


Nothing gains as much attention as the
national PARTY conventions which are held
every four years Oben presidential can
didates and vice presidential candidates
are selected.


This year all eyes are turned tOuoTd
San Francisco where the Republican dele
gates win nominate a standard bearer.
Senator Barry GoldWoteY from Arizona
is leading the field and his detYa ctyOS are
using all methods to IMPEDE his nominal
ton.


Few min recall that the same man Wk0
now occupies the White House, Lyndon B.
Johnson, u0s not known for his far reach
ing support of civil rights measures Mhen
he wos chosen to run with the late bTesi-
dent. NoaV, as the President of the United
States, he must uphold the Cons tttutton,
though sOhen he Was a senator from Texas,
he uoted against some Of the very Things
he now must ere cute.


The party system wiH continue and the.
man chosen to head the Tesbe ctsUe P0Tty>s
tickets viii haze to do as any otheT man
uho is v0ted into the White H0uSe-he WpH
uphold the l0aV Of Ouy land.


DELUXE

W0nlen III Tic WVLA01 0ASSSS~ -"
the latest fashions. The next
group Of miladies will be dressed
in lion cloths, high boots, rain
coats or bouffant skirts.


1t 10 the city Of opera, "sick
comedy. beach houses, sky
scrapers. townhouses. swank
motels, yachts. fishing boats,
freeways and highspanned brid-
ges.


I like to visit the city on the
hills and we we're delighted with
the chilly weather. However. two
nights the thermometer dropped
past fifty and we were really
complaining.


Californians are like colonists.
The San Franciscans feel quite
differently toward the Los Ange-
les dwellers. They talk about the
division between north and south
parts Of the state as II civil war
we're ready to erupt.


The newspaper publishers as
ISOLATION convention ended on a
grand note with the last meeting
being held at the Christian Bro
theirs school and winery In Napa
Valley.


We drove on a chartered bus
past Oakland, Vallejo and several
smaller towns before reaching
the winding road In the valley.
Rows and rows Of grape plants
stretched across the rolling land.


The setting was tranquil and
near perfect as the Brothers
Gregory and Norman explained
the schools purposes and the
financial backing of the wine In
dustry.


While In the city we heard that
some members of the city coun-
ell we're hoping to pass an ordi-
nance forbidding walking on the
bridges because so many persons
had committed suicide.


The park in the heart Of town
is another sight of San Francisco
you can never forget. Here were
all kinds of men and women. Some
sleeping. some reading, some
making speeches and others
merely standing. Union Square
rivals Central Park as a beautiful
green spot In crowded metropo-
lis.


Our trip back home started
after we had been interviewed by
a vivacious teacher from New
York. Miss Lou LuTour. She
has a radio, series and she is
spending untold hours preparinga
documentary series on the Negro
Press. We invited her to stop in
Phoenix fewdays before return
ing to Gotham.


The drive home was not as hec-
tic as our drive to San Francisco.
We were more relaxed and had
more time to enjoy the scenery.
California Is beautiful, but Ari-
iona comes first.


Edward and spent the night in
Los Angeles at the home Of MIR.
and Mrs. Edwin Dec onge. twas
good to see them and we talked
until nearly midnight Sunday.


Early Monday morning we hit
the road for Phoenix and made
the wrong turn on the freeway.
We ended up in Dairy Valley on
Artesian Drive. We said 1t was
interesting although we lost about
a half hour. never knew that
there we're SO many cows just a
stones throw from the City of
Angels.


My spouse remarked that more
Americans should get off of the
freeways and see more of the
country.


Before long we connected to the
main HIGHWAY and resumed Ollr

Siqhts and Sounds
ELolsg BANKS
